title: Understanding Cybersecurity Myths: Experiencing a Cyberattack with Financial Impact
description: Explore a simulated cyberattack on a business to understand real cyber risks and debunk common cybersecurity myths. See the impacts and vulnerabilities organizations face.
author: Maurice Lambert

slides.title: Cybersecurity Risks and Myths versus Real-World attacks

content: Financial Costs: Cyberattacks cost billions every year.
Reputation Damage: A single breach can ruin a brand's trust.
Privacy Threats: Data leaks expose personal information, compromising privacy.
High Costs: Cybersecurity solutions are expensive and often ineffective.
Insufficient Protection: Many defenses fail against threats.
False Sense of Security: Even with major investments, businesses remain vulnerable.

texts.content: To demonstrate these challenges, we will explore a simulated cyberattack that exposes these vulnerabilities and debunks common cybersecurity myths.

slides.title: When Security Practices Fail: Cracked Authentication Can Drain a Company's Funds
The Perfect Target: Small Startup, Big Funding, Single Point of Failure

texts.content:
Sylphora Dynamics is a small IoT & logistics startup based in Marseille.
Earlier this year, the company successfully raised €5 million in funding to accelerate its growth.
With fewer than 10 employees and no dedicated finance team, all banking and financial operations are managed directly by the CEO, Henri Brosquet, through his professional email account.

A group of attackers identifies this as a potential weakness.
Their objective: gain access to the CEO's email account in order to initiate discreet transfers from the company's investment funds.

slides.title: OSINT: The Public Data That Fuels Cyberattacks

texts.content: OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) refers to the collection of publicly available information used to profile a company or individual.
For attackers, public data is the first weapon, it helps them understand structures, targets, and weaknesses.

content: Social networks like LinkedIn are a goldmine of intelligence: job titles, tools, partners, and even email patterns.
Press releases, websites, and GitHub commits often reveal technical and organizational insights.

texts.content:
In a real attack, everything begins with what's already publicly available.
Attackers don't guess, they research.

slides.title: From Public Data to Password Cracking: The First Step of the Attack

texts.content: After collecting public information, we identified two professional email addresses and a login portal accessible online.

The first realistic attack scenario: a brute-force attempt on these accounts.
Rather than random guessing, attackers often use password dictionaries based on the most common passwords used in a specific country or language.
Attackers don't need sophistication, just our bad habits.

slides.title: A New Path: From Failed Credentials to a Technical Weakness

content: After the brute-force phase, some valid employee credentials are found, but not the CEO's.
Using the newly found credentials, attackers try to log in, but reach a two-factor authentication wall.
Looking for another entry point, they experiment with how the login form reacts to unexpected input.
One of these tests triggers a server error, displaying technical details.
Searching this error message online points to a database query issue, a classic sign of a SQL injection vulnerability.
They gained access without needing a password and were able to directly exfiltrate all data.

slides.title: Mass Credential Extraction: Full User Database Compromised

texts.content:
After gaining access through the SQL injection, the attackers automate the process.
Using a simple script, they exfiltrate all user accounts, every hashed password, and all TOTP 2FA secrets stored in the database.
This gives them everything they need to rebuild the company's entire authentication system on their own machine, completely bypassing any security controls.

slides.title: Targeted Password Bruteforce: User-Specific Wordlists Built from Public Data

texts.content: After extracting the password hashes, attackers create personalized wordlists using public info: names, birth years, city, and data from the website.
Each user's list contains 36 million potential passwords.
On an old Linux i3 machine, generating and testing the entire 36-million-entry wordlist took only 101 seconds per user, even with a simple, non-optimized Python script.
However, parallel processing (multi-core CPUs) can reduce cracking time proportionally to the number of cores, modern GPUs can accelerate it by 10x to 100x, and ASICs by up to 100,000x.

slides.title: Leveraging Breach Data: Identifying Passwords Reused Across the Internet

texts.content: With employee names and corporate email formats, attackers can check publicly known data-breach collections to see whether any team members have had passwords exposed in past incidents.
If an employee reused the same or similar password across services, attackers may recover valid credentials without needing to guess or crack anything.

slides.title: Highly Convincing Phishing: Impersonation, Punycode Domains & Realistic Email Cloning

texts.content: With the CEO's email address, and even multiple compromised employee accounts, attackers could send highly convincing phishing emails (though this is not the method used in our demonstration).
In our scenario, they register a Punycode domain mimicking the real banking provider and clone a legitimate bank email to make the message fully credible.

The goal is to lure the CEO to a fake login page to capture his username, password, and 2FA code, or to deliver a crafted email exploiting a vulnerability in his mail application, or a malicious attachment capable of compromising his workstation.

slides.title: Final Stage of the Attack: Credential Theft Through Malicious File Execution

content:
Phishing leads to ZIP file download:
  • The ZIP contains a fake PDF disguised as a .lnk shortcut.

User clicks the deceptive .lnk file:
  • A hidden command runs in the background while the PDF opens normally.

Malware extracts KeePass credentials:
  • Modifies the KeePass configuration file.
  • Deploy a malware to send the credentials back to the attacker's Command and Control (C2) server.

slides.title: Practical Cybersecurity Tips: Defend Against Attacks on Personal and Business Accounts
Essential Personal Cybersecurity Best Practices

content: Always lock your workstation with a strong password
Use a password manager and generate random, unique passwords
Avoid public networks and do not handle confidential data in public places
Keep all systems and applications regularly updated
Use multiple email accounts (personal, professional, sensitive services)
Never input confidential data into AI tools
Limit installed apps and browser extensions
Stay cautious with unexpected emails
Do not follow the actions requested in suspicious emails

slides.title: Practical Cybersecurity Tips for Everyday Protection

content:
Automatically clear cookies and site data when closing your browser
to reduce tracking and protect your privacy

Use private browsing mode for everyday online activity
to limit data retention and exposure

Verify sensitive or unusual requests through a separate channel
(phone, chat, in-person) and never use the contact details from the suspicious email

slides.title: Key Professional Cybersecurity Recommendations

content: Deploy EDR / EPP / Antivirus solutions to strengthen endpoint protection
Avoid using AI to generate code unless strong code-review expertise is available
Enforce two-factor authentication (2FA), especially for employees with lower cybersecurity awareness
Build a DevSecOps team as early as possible to integrate security into development workflows
Enable full disk encryption on all company devices to protect data in case of loss or theft

slides.title: Practical Cybersecurity Tips for Organizations

content: Use Single Sign-On (SSO) to reduce the number of passwords employees must manage
Limit mandatory password changes, but enforce strong password policies
Create an email rule that moves all messages from your internal domain to a dedicated folder, making spoofed look-alike domain emails easier to detect

slides.title: Conclusion: Breaking Common Cybersecurity Myths
Debunking Cybersecurity Myths: The Hard Truths

content: 2FA is often bypassed, phishing, compromised user devices, or server attacks can render 2FA ineffective
EDR / AV / SIEM cannot stop most attacks, attackers rely on legitimate administrative actions that evade detection and blocking
Password vaults are only as secure as the device, if the user's device is compromised, all stored credentials are at risk
An email from the correct address doesn't prove identity, sender addresses can be spoofed or impersonated
